description: The physical parts of a computer.

slides.title: What is Hardware?
slides.content:
# The Body ü¶¥

Physical components that make up a computer system.
- If you can kick it, it's hardware.
- Software is the instructions (soul) that run on it.

slides.title: CPU (Central Processing Unit)
slides.content:
# The Brain üß†

Executes instructions.
- **Gigahertz (GHz)**: Billions of cycles per second.
- **Cores**: Independent processing units (Dual-core, Quad-core).

slides.title: RAM (Random Access Memory)
slides.content:
# Short-term Memory üí≠

Volatile memory for active tasks.
- Fast but erased when power off.
- More RAM = More apps open at once.

slides.title: Storage: HDD vs SSD
slides.content:
# Long-term Memory üìö

- **HDD (Hard Disk)**: Spinning magnetic platters. Cheap, slow.
- **SSD (Solid State)**: Flash chips (like USB). Fast, silent, durable.
- Always choose SSD for your OS.

slides.title: Motherboard
slides.content:
# The Spine ü¶¥

Main circuit board connecting everything.
- CPU socket, RAM slots, GPU slots.
- **BIOS/UEFI**: Tiny firmware to start the boot process.

slides.title: GPU (Graphics Card)
slides.content:
# The Artist üé®

Specialized processor for rendering images.
- Thousands of tiny cores.
- Essential for Gaming, Video Editing, and AI/Machine Learning.

slides.title: Memory Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which component loses its data when the computer is turned off?

slides.title: Input/Output Devices
slides.content:
# Talk and Listen üó£Ô∏è

- **Input**: Mouse, Keyboard, Mic.
- **Output**: Monitor, Speakers, Printer.

slides.title: Binary and Bits
slides.content:
# 0s and 1s üëæ

Computers run on electricity (On/Off).
- **Bit**: 0 or 1.
- **Byte**: 8 bits (Can represent one character).
- **Kilobyte**: 1024 bytes.

slides.title: Logic Gates
slides.content:
# Digital Logic üö™

Physical transistors forming logic.
- **AND**: Both on $\to$ On.
- **OR**: One on $\to$ On.
- **NOT**: On $\to$ Off.
Billions of these make a CPU.

slides.title: Moore's Law
slides.content:
# Shrinking üî¨

"The number of transistors on a chip doubles every ~2 years."
- Why computers get faster and smaller.
- Slowing down recently due to physical limits (atoms are small!).

slides.title: Cooling Systems
slides.content:
# Heat Management ‚ùÑÔ∏è

Electricity causes heat.
- **Heat Sink**: Metal fins to dissipate heat.
- **Fans**: Move air.
- **Liquid Cooling**: Water loop for high performance.

slides.title: Power Supply (PSU)
slides.content:
# Food ‚ö°

Converts AC wall power to DC for PC components.
- Must be stable.
- Modular cables allow cleaner builds.

slides.title: Brain Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which component is primarily responsible for executing program instructions?

slides.title: Ports and Interfaces
slides.content:
# Connections üîå

- **USB**: Universal Serial Bus (Connects everything).
- **HDMI/DisplayPort**: Video.
- **Ethernet**: Wired Internet.
- **Thunderbolt**: High speed data/video.

slides.title: Embedded Systems
slides.content:
# Hidden Computers üìü

Tiny computers inside other devices.
- Washing machines, Cars, Traffic lights.
- Usually Low power, Real-time OS.

slides.title: Quantum Computing
slides.content:
# The Future? ‚öõÔ∏è

Uses Quantum Bits (Qubits).
- Superposition: Can be 0 and 1 at same time.
- Exponentially faster for specific math problems.
- Still experimental.

slides.title: Von Neumann Architecture
slides.content:
# The Standard üèõÔ∏è

Design of almost all modern computers.
- Shared memory for Data and Instructions.
- Fetch-Decode-Execute cycle.

slides.title: Hardware Summary
slides.content:
# Recap üìù

- **CPU** thinks, **RAM** remembers now, **SSD** remembers forever.
- **Binary** underlies everything.
- Hardware relies on physics (electricity).
